awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2017
awd_abstract_narration:
This is an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology, under the program Broadening Participation of Groups Underrepresented in Biology. The fellow, Kristin Hook, is conducting research and receiving training that is increasing the participation of groups underrepresented in biology, and is being mentored by Heidi Fisher at the University of Maryland (UM). The research explores the consequences of sperm cell shape on their function. Despite sharing a common goal to reach and fertilize an egg, sperm cells vary greatly. Rodent sperm are particularly diverse; not only do they vary within and across species, many feature a mysterious hook on their head, and a rare few exhibit collective behaviors in which they form aggregations of several cells that swim together. The significance of this variation is poorly understood. Using several species of deer mice, the fellow is exploring the relationship between sperm shape and their unique interactions. The research and training environment at UM is exceptionally diverse, with underrepresented minorities (URMs) comprising one-fourth of the student population. To broaden participation and engender an inclusive culture in biology, the fellow is collaborating with established university programs and local magnet schools to recruit and integrate URMs and women into lab and field research by providing hands-on training and mentorship. Moreover, the Fellow is sharing results of her research through (1) public talks on her research in both English and Spanish and (2) online platforms, including postings on her blog ("Animal Behavior Research Oddities") and Twitter.  

The fellow is characterizing how subtle morphological changes (e.g., minor differences in head shape) and extensive modifications (e.g., hook presence or absence) influence sperm interactions and swimming performance using a comparative, cross-species approach among species of deer mice (genus Peromyscus). She is also examining the biological relevance of sperm aggregates and identifying the genetic basis of the hook. The fellow is testing the hypotheses that (1) species with shared aggregate geometries exhibit similar sperm head geometries, (2) species with shared morphologies exhibit similar motility, (3) sperm aggregates enhance swimming performance, and (4) species lacking hooks do not form aggregates. Together this research advances our understanding of the evolution of reproductive traits, the molecular forces defining cell design, and the importance of sperm structure, which more broadly has implications for public health in identifying the unique cellular features contributing to sperm motility and, ultimately, male fitness.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology was awarded to Dr. Kristin Hook, who conducted research and received training at the University of Maryland, College Park (UMCP), under the mentorship of Dr. Heidi Fisher to increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. 

The purpose of this fellowship was to explore the consequences of sperm cell shape on their function to identify which unique features contribute to their swimming performance. Despite sharing a common goal to reach and fertilize an egg, sperm cells are one of the most diverse cell types known. Rodent sperm are particularly diverse; not only do they vary within and across species, many feature a mysterious hook on their head, and a rare few exhibit collective behaviors in which they form motile groups of multiple cells that swim together. While this variation is well known, its significance is poorly understood. Female promiscuity is thought to be an important driver of this variation. When females mate with more than one male in a reproductive cycle, males are hypothesized to evolve traits that allow them to outcompete rivals in their race to the egg, which can include sperm shape or even their ability to form sperm aggregates. Using several microscopic techniques, the fellow investigated how subtle differences in head shape and the presence or absence of the sperm hook influence sperm interactions and swimming performance across species of Peromyscus mice, which offer a tremendous opportunity to study variation in reproductive traits and test predictions about them because closely related species naturally vary in their levels of female promiscuity. Fundamental questions that the fellow has pursued over the course of this fellowship includes:  

1) How does sperm shape influence their ability to form collective groups that swim together?

2) Do sperm aggregates swim better in more complex environments?  

3) What is the purpose of the hook that is present on most rodent sperm heads?  

The fellow tested the hypotheses that (1) species with similar aggregation behaviors exhibit similar sperm head shapes, (2) species with shared head shapes exhibit similar swimming abilities, (3) sperm aggregates enhance swimming performance, and (4) the presence of the hook facilitates the formation of sperm aggregates. 

Results from this project reveal that (1) sperm with wider heads aggregate more, supporting the hypotheses that sperm head shape impacts sperm aggregation and that species with similar aggregation behaviors exhibit similar sperm head shapes, (2) species with similar head shapes do not exhibit similar swimming abilities, which suggests that other factors are important for their movements, (3) aggregates vary among species but overall do not perform better than single sperm in their swimming performance; however, for species that do aggregate the most, aggregates are significantly faster within promiscuous species, and (4) sperm with smaller hooks trend toward forming more aggregates than sperm with larger hooks, but sperm cells with a reduced or absent hook on their head can still fertilize eggs and move similarly to sperm cells with a normal hook on their head. Together, these exciting results on sperm traits suggest that even subtle changes in sperm form, namely a wider head and shorter hook, can contribute to large differences in sperm interactions and movement patterns. They also suggest that the apical hook is not critical for fertility or aggregation, thus warranting further investigation of this perplexing trait. Moreover, these results support the hypothesis that female promiscuity can lead to important differences in sperm traits that allow them to be more competitive when racing against a rival to fertilize eggs. Ultimately, this research advances our understanding of the importance of sperm structure and function, the forces defining cell design, and the evolution of reproductive traits. Basic research on these traits is important because it can be useful for optimizing assisted reproductive technologies and conservation programs as well as shed light on what unique cellular features influence sperm motility and fertility, which is not only critical for understanding sexual selection – a major driving force that generates biodiversity – but is also important for public health.  

The research and training environment of the fellow at UMCP is exceptionally diverse, with underrepresented minorities comprising one-fourth of the student population. To broaden participation and engender an inclusive culture in biology, the fellow recruited and integrated eight students from groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences into lab research to provide hands-on training, mentorship, and guidance in both independent and honors projects. These projects will result in several published manuscripts in addition to those that will be produced from the research described above. Moreover, the fellow has shared results from this research and on sperm biology more generally through (1) guest lectures at UMCP, (2) a research talk at a public comedy show, (3) a podcast recording, and (4) online platforms, including postings on her blog and on Twitter.
